descriptionSet.description: A group of women are depicted in a hammam in this image. A table with tea and fruits as well as decorative elements like a lion and a incense holder can be seen. One of the woman depicted in this advertisement has dark skin whereas the others are distinctively white. The background shows certain architectural elements of a hammam with a pool in the middle.

inscription.text: J. Margerison & Co. Ltd. Preston - England

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: Advertisement for Margerison's Superfine Bath Soap

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: A group of women are depicted in a hammam in this image. A table with tea and fruits as well as decorative elements like a lion and a incense holder can be seen. One of the woman depicted in this advertisement has dark skin whereas the others are distinctively white. The background shows certain architectural elements of a hammam with a pool in the middle. (gs)
text-en: Margerison's Superfine Bath Soap
text-en: J. Margerison & Co. Ltd. Preston - England

explanatory comments/crosstagging: With imagery drawn from an imagined Turkish hamaam (communal bath), the Orientalist bath soap advertisement in this image simultaneously perpetuates racial caricatures. The Black woman in this image is probably a slave and clearly on display. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: However the advertisement also hints at the erotic possibilities of collective bathing through multiple sexual gazes: of all the women admiring the body of the half clothed white woman: of the black woman watching the white woman and of the consumers of the advertisement who could gaze upon all of them collectively. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Given the obsession with lighter skin in India, it might seem like a coincidence that a number of luxury soaps were white in color. It is important to remember that soap was predicated on a notion of superiority. Over time whiteness came to be associated with cleanliness, and cleanliness in turn was linked to civilization and class. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: According to Anne McClintock soaps like Pears played a decisive role in colonialsm as its advertising carried a powerful racial ideology she refers to as "commodity racism". Many soap advertising images in the colonial period conveyed the message that soap is the means to bring civilization. For instance, one ad from 1899 argued that "The first step toward lightening THE WHITE MAN'S BURDEN is through teaching the virtues of cleanliness. PEARS' SOAP is a potent fact in brightening the dark corners of the earth as civilization advances." (citation taken from http://science.jrank.org/pages/8820/Consumerism-SOAP.html#ixzz1Vf1A9MCv). Thus, soap was one of the major symbolic carriers of whiteness and imperialism and Victorian notions of gender. ()(la)
